info.game_comments:
Bob Blake game 5.

New 5-day winnings record.

(1, 1).clue: Geronimo rode in this president's 1905 inaugural parade, & so did the Rough Riders

(2, 1).clue: The 7-day week is derived from this book of the Bible

(3, 1).clue: The naked-mole rat found in northern Kenya is a burrowing rodent that lacks this sense

(4, 1).clue: 2 Alpine passes & 1 breed of dog are named for this French-born Italian saint

(5, 1).clue: The most famous George we know whose middle name was Armstrong

(1, 2).clue: In Bush's parade these California fruit characters rode on the Presidential Council on Fitness float

(2, 2).clue: This ancient timepiece was called a gnomon by the Greeks meaning "one who knows"

(3, 2).clue: The mule deer is so named because of these large features

(4, 2).clue: "The Day the Rope Broke" is a famous book about an 1865 climbing accident on this peak

(1, 3).clue: His parade featured many types of missiles & a PT boat

(2, 3).clue: The Anglo-Saxons divided their days into 3 parts: morningtide, noontide & this

(3, 3).clue: It's the offspring of a male tiger & a female lion

(4, 3).clue: The word "alp" is believed to have evolved from the Latin "albus", meaning this color

(5, 3).clue: It was Joel Harris' middle name; just ask Brer Rabbit

(6, 3).clue: [audio]"Love lift us up where we belong..."

(1, 4).clue: In 1913, this future president, then a West Point cadet, marched in Wilson's parade

(2, 4).clue: In the proposed "World Calendar", an extra day called "Year Day" would come at the end of this month

(3, 4).clue: The Viking name for this tusked Arctic animal meant "whale horse"

(4, 4).clue: This Alpine goat-antelope is prized for its hide, which is made into a very soft leather

(5, 4).clue: Cole Porter's middle name; it's also Frank Sinatra's

(1, 5).clue: He was the only president inaugurated in two different cities

(2, 5).clue: A law discovered by Galileo led Christian Huygens to build the 1st clock regulated by one of these

(3, 5).clue: The world's most potent venom is secreted from the skin of one of these amphibians

(4, 5).clue: Once a humble herdsman's hut, it's now a favorite style for mountain homes

(5, 5).clue: The middle name of the actress who was "On the Waterfront" before she went "North By Northwest"

(1, 1).clue: Condition in which the sharp edge of a nail grows into the flesh of a toe, usually the big one

(2, 1).clue: This country sent more than 90% of the troops, equipment & supplies aiding South Korea

(3, 1).clue: This Canadian province is home to the Royal Winnipeg Ballet

(4, 1).clue: The Bob Hope Comedy Fund has been set up at this New Haven university's drama school

(5, 1).clue: Though Polish is a Slavic language, it uses this alphabet

(6, 1).clue: Iran, Libya & Cuba are on a U.S. government list of nations that support this violent activity

(1, 2).clue: Sometimes a pacifier will soothe a baby suffering from this gastrointestinal pain

(2, 2).clue: Because of policy disputes, President Truman replaced this general with Lt. General Matthew Ridgway

(3, 2).clue: "Rond de jambe" means a rotary movement of this body part, on the floor or in the air

(4, 2).clue: Founded in 1789, this D.C. university is the oldest Catholic college in the U.S.

(5, 2).clue: Country whose languages include Gujarati, Assamese & Punjabi

(6, 2).clue: Kids can spell this 28-letter word that means "opposition to the withdrawal of support from a church"

(1, 3).clue: Immediate "REM" sleep is a characteristic symptom of the sleeping attacks caused by this disease

(2, 3).clue: After the war, this latitude line roughly separated North & South Korea

(3, 3).clue: Helena & Hermia are characters in "The Dream", a ballet based on this Shakespearean play

(4, 3).clue: Moor's Indian Charity School, founded about 1750, is the ancestor of this N.H. Ivy League college

(5, 3).clue: At his 1969 investiture at Caernarvon Castle, Prince Charles spoke these 2 languages

(6, 3).clue: The willful destruction of property named for a Germanic people who sacked Rome in the 5th century

(1, 4).clue: Ortho & Wyeth-Ayerst are the major manufacturers of these pills in the U.S.

(2, 4).clue: U.S. troops landing at this seaport on 9/15/50 turned the course of the war in the Allies' favor

(3, 4).clue: In 1985 this princess revived the Monte Carlo Ballet, as her mother had wished

(4, 4).clue: "Sister school" that's involved in investing $7 million to redevelop So. Hadley, Mass., where it's located

(5, 4).clue: The only country whose official language is Catalan is this small one in the Pyrenees Mountains

(6, 4).clue: If your can of green beans bulges out, it may be contaminated with this food poisoning

(1, 5).clue: Component usually used in cough syrup as a solvent for ingredients that won't mix well with water

(2, 5).clue: From Oct. 25, 1951 to the end of the hostilities in 1953, peace talks continued in this village

(3, 5).clue: This "Regal" ballet company was formerly known as the Sadler's Wells Ballet

(4, 5).clue: Tulane University is the largest privately run institution of higher learning in this state

(5, 5).clue: Most people of this small European nation speak Letzeburgisch, a German dialect

(6, 5).clue: From a Greek word for "pleasure", it's the belief that pleasure is life's greatest good

(0, 0).clue: The next-to-last chapter of this novel is entitled "The Knitting Done"
